1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:05): ok suse is workin on a 15gb ide drive but there is also an 80gb sata drive hooked up and its not recognizing it how to i get suse to even acknowledge the drive?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:05): i_is_cat, does the hard disk show up in dev?
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:06): but if you piss around in the control center
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:06): but it said it doesnt exist
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:06): what is the mount command you tried?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:06): In Yast? what control center?
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:07): i was just lookin around to see if there were any apps that might help me find it
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:07): KDE might see the disk if hal is reporting it, but hal is not my area

1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:08): and like i said it listed /dev/sda1 and /dev/sda5 and said they're ntfs but didnt resolve a size and when i tried to mount it by right clicking and selecting the only option (mount) it said it doesnt exist
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:08): ok, go to the command like and type:
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:08): mount /dev/sdaX /mnt ( where X is an NTFS parition you want to mount )
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:09): tell me what it says
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:10): there are 4 partitions on the drive i want to wipe out 3 of them
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:10): but i need to copy data over first
dd27f6cf861109dbad29f1c66068e550 (02:10): mkdir /dev/sda1 will make the dir exist
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:11): Thats not a good idea
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:11): doesnt sound like a good idea
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:11): sda1 isnt spose to be a dir its spose to be a device
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:11): adamant1988, you dont make device nodes using mkdir
dd27f6cf861109dbad29f1c66068e550 (02:12): what are we looking for exactly?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:12): then the device is not found
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:13): sdx is scsi, im not sure if the sata prefix is the same
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:13): how do i get it to recognize?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:14): can you see the disk in the BIOS
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:14): the drive is good i just had windows going on it then put suse on it
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:14): what do you mean 'control center kinda sees it'
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:15): i told ya already.. it shows /dev/sda1 and /dev/sda5 and when i right click and select mount it says no such device

e3b99d6e1a445276f5d8d54a19d127c8 (02:16): for anyone that might care: WOL in 10.1 didn't work because the driver module for marvell chips, sk98lin apparently lost this functionality. the newer module skge does support it.
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:16): i_is_cat, your kernel will know better than KDE ;) use gnome
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:18): only from a kde-lover would i hear 'ownz' anyway back to this disk problem
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:19): you think its a kernel issue?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:19): if the device is not in /dev then either a) KDE is wrong, or b) hald or another hardware abstraction system sees it, in which case I cant help
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:19): or the drive is fucked
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:19): nah like i said the drive was just running windows and suse both
dd27f6cf861109dbad29f1c66068e550 (02:19): i_is_cat, dumb... question... did you try unplugging it and pluggin it back in?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:20): adamant1988, are u winding him up
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:20): well sata cables DO have a tendency to get loose
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:20): from what your saying your running suse off a partion on it
1e85f36b4141649725162f1942d4110b (02:20): its just every time i reboot this machine it cant find a hard drive
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:21): is suse on the disk your looking for?
cf05c41bbc5e690d7086d0f3c0f48d89 (02:21): or is this a secondary disk
